Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Engineering Strong, Highly Conductive Nanotube Fibers Via Fusion
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this NSF-Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) project funded by the Division of Chemistry and the Civil, Mechanical, Manufacturing and Innovation Division, Professors Yung Joon Jung, Carol Livermore-Clifford, Moneesh Upmanyu, and David Kaeli of Northeastern University are studying how to create high-performance carbon fibers that could be used for applications in aerospace, high power density energy storage, and lightweight cabling/wiring. The main challenge of creating such fibers is that they need to be mechanically strong while also being exceptional conductors of heat and electricity. To accomplish this goal, the researchers are studying how to fuse networks that contain many nanometer-sized carbon tubes ("carbon nanotubes") into a larger, more seamless structure. The variables being studied include ways to organize the carbon nanotubes into the network and to use electric voltage to fuse the carbon nanotubes together. Experimental studies, computational simulations, and data mining techniques are being applied to understand the complex relationships between the structure of the fused networks and how they perform.

The combination of superior electronic, thermal, and mechanical properties makes carbon nanotube networks an ideal building block for high-performance multifunctional materials, but these advantages are eroded in van der Waals connected networks. If van der Waals interactions were replaced with covalent bonds to create macroscopic seamless carbon nanostructures, performance should increase significantly. This research project is focusing on a novel carbon nanostructure engineering process called nanotube fusion. The method controls input voltages across the network to create covalently bonded molecular junctions (cross-links) between carbon nanotubes, transforming them into larger diameter single-walled carbon nanotubes, multi-walled carbon nanotubes, or multi-layered graphene nanoribbons with measurable property improvement. The research is engaging interdependent experimental, simulation, and data mining efforts to enable scalable multifunctional fibers. The experimental parameters include fusion polarity, frequency, voltage, source-on-time, and external temperature, as well as carbon nanotube structure, assembly process and initial fiber architecture. Characterization data and coarse-grained atomistic simulation of fused fibers relate physical properties to structure and structure to processing. These efforts are complemented by statistical data mining efforts to extract the complex relationship between fiber processing and their properties. The team is working to involve high school students directly in the research; to enable research opportunities for undergraduates from a diversity of backgrounds; and to create symposia on materials science and on multifunctional nanostructured networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon nanotube-based materials are valuable in part because they are strong and stiff and conduct both heat and electricity well.  However, fibrous materials made up of many carbon nanotubes do not perform as well as would be expected based on how strong, stiff, and conductive individual carbon nanotubes are.  One reason why these materials perform less well than they could is that the carbon nanotubes from which they are made are not connected together firmly enough. This research demonstrated that the carbon nanotubes that make up carbon nanotube fibers can be bonded together by passing an electrical current through the fiber.  The combination of electrical energy and generated heat allows the fibers to perform better, in a way that is closer to ideal carbon nanotube performance.  Treatment with electrical currents is a simple way of improving the properties of carbon nanotube yarns that is straightforward to use in practice and can therefore have a large impact on the manufacture of carbon nanotube based materials.

One challenge of making fibers perform in a better, more ideal way is that there are a great many factors that affect the structure of the fibers and how they perform.  How to control all of these factors in order to achieve the highest performing fibers is not obvious, and determining the right combination of factors can be very time-consuming.  To address this challenge, the project used a combination of experiments, simulations, and data mining to efficiently determine which combinations of factors provide the best performance.

One outcome of this project was the knowledge of how different levels, durations, and patterns of electrical current flow result in different molecular structures within the fibers.  Small carbon nanotubes were seen to merge together into larger, multi-walled carbon nanotubes and into graphene nanoribbons.  In addition, carbon nanotubes were observed to merge together as if they were being zipped together.  These observed mergers showed that the electrical current treatment had a powerful ability to turn many smaller carbon nanotubes into a larger material that can act as a whole.

A second outcome of this project was the demonstration that carbon nanotube fibers can be made stronger and more thermally conductive through treatment with electrical currents.  Thermal conductivity was increased by up to a factor of ten when the fibers were both heated and electrically fused, reaching 190 W/mK, the highest known value for fibers with diameters of greater than 100 micrometers. Treating the fibers with higher currents generally improved the average linear strength performance of the fibers more than lower current treatments did.  Shorter treatment times also improved fiber performance by minimizing the formation of defects.  The maximum average improvement in the linear strength of the fibers was 45%. 

A third outcome of this project was the demonstration that coarse-grained atomic simulations can be used to accurately predict the behavior of carbon nanotube-based materials.  The simulations were found to be an effective way of describing both the original carbon nanotube materials and the materials after the carbon nanotubes are fused together by current flow.  Our study captures the effect of some of the more important fusion-induced structural variables, offering a rational design strategy for fusion variables. We show that graphitization is a key structural transformation that changes the mechanical response qualitatively (ductile to brittle) and makes the networks increasingly viscoelastic.

A fourth outcome of this project was the development of a data mining based scheme for predicting the effect of these structural variables. The knowledge gained was used to effectively direct the optimization of these materials by identifying how coupled parameter variations can yield the best-performing materials.  

The final outcome of this project was its broader impact on education and extending participation in STEM fields.  Undergraduates from Northeastern University participated in the research during the school year, and high school and undergraduate students from other schools participated in the research through a summer program.  Our summer programs effectively reached communities that are underrepresented in STEM, including veteran and community college students.  Another achievement is our ongoing contribution to material databases at NIST.

Modified by: Carol Livermore

Images (1 of )
  • Optical microscope and scanning electron microscope images of carbon nanotube fibers before and after electrical fusion. The alignment of the filaments increases dramatically after fusion.
    Yung Joon Jung
    Copyrighted
    Carol Livermore
    Fused carbon nanotube fibers
  • Fractional change in linear strength predicted from data mining as a function of the power level during fusion and the total energy delivered to the fiber during fusion. Dark red indicates an increase of 40%, and dark blue indicates a decrease of 30%.
    Xiangyu Li and Sanwei Liu
    Copyrighted
    Carol Livermore
    Data-enabled strength predictions
  • Fractional change in linear strength measured in experiments as a function of the power level and total energy delivered to the fiber during fusion. Dark red indicates an increase of 55%, and dark blue indicates a decrease of 30%. The results agree well with the predictions from data mining.
    Sanwei Liu
    Copyrighted
    Carol Livermore
    Measured strength
  • Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of electrically fused CNT fibers: (Top) Schematic of treated fiber and TEM images of the surface and inside of the fiber. (Bottom) TEM images of fused fibers before and after 90 degree rotation revealing the formation of seamless graphenic nanoribbons.
    Yung Joon Jung
    Copyrighted
    Carol Livermore
    Transmission electron microscope images showing graphenic nanoribbons
  • Large-scale coarse-grained computations of carbon nanotube networks with fusion-induced changes in nanotube-scale structure. Our study shows that alignment of the nanotubes has a dramatic effect on the load-bearing characteristics of the entire network.
    Moneesh Upmanyu
    Carol Livermore
    Large-scale coarse-grained computation of carbon nanotube network with fusion induced-changes
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Carbon nanotube-based materials are valuable in part because they are strong and stiff and conduct both heat and electricity well. However, fibrous materials made up of many carbon nanotubes do not perform as well as would be expected based on how strong, stiff, and conductive individual carbon nanotubes are. One reason why these materials perform less well than they could is that the carbon nanotubes from which they are made are not connected together firmly enough. This research demonstrated that the carbon nanotubes that make up carbon nanotube fibers can be bonded together by passing an electrical current through the fiber. Treatment with electrical currents is a simple way of improving the properties of carbon nanotube yarns that is straightforward to use in practice and can therefore have a large impact on the manufacture of carbon nanotube based materials. One challenge of making fibers perform in a better, more ideal way is that there are a great many factors that affect the structure of the fibers and how they perform. The knowledge gained was used to effectively direct the optimization of these materials by identifying how coupled parameter variations can yield the best-performing materials. The final outcome of this project was its broader impact on education and extending participation in STEM fields. Undergraduates from Northeastern University participated in the research during the school year, and high school and undergraduate students from other schools participated in the research through a summer program. Our summer programs effectively reached communities that are underrepresented in STEM, including veteran and community college students.
